name: Qakbot
notes: Operation Duck Hunt on August 29, 2023 removed Qakbot malware from over 700,000 infected computers worldwide and seized $8.6 million in illicit cryptocurrencyhttps://www.justice.gov/usao-cdca/pr/qakbot-malware-disrupted-international-cyber-takedown#:~:text=Qakbot%20Malware%20Infected%20More%20Than,Millions%20of%20Dollars%20in%20Damage.
mitigation: Delete Qakbot malware with uninstaller, patch systems, train users to recognize phishing.

name: Necurs
notes: The engine behind some of the largest malspam campaigns of 2016. Its brief takedown/outage in mid-2016 correlated with a sharp drop in Locky spam.
tactics_techniques: Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment; Obfuscated Files or Information; Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Massive spam botnet responsible for distributing Locky and Dridex."}

name: Emotet
notes: Emotet's activity in 2018 grew significantly. It became the main dropper for TrickBot, which in turn dropped Ryuk ransomware.
tactics_techniques: Phishing; VB; Command Shell; C2; Credential Dumping; Email Collection; Deobfuscate/Decode
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Dominated 2018 as the primary distribution botnet for other major threats."}
mitigation: Block malicious attachments; Disable macros; User training; Network segmentation.

name: Emotet
notes: Began a major resurgence in 2017, evolving into a primary delivery vehicle for other malware, including TrickBot and Ryuk.
tactics_techniques: Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment; Visual Basic; Windows Command Shell; Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols; OS Credential Dumping; Email Collection: Local Email Collection
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Evolved from a banking trojan into a prolific malware downloader (Dropper-as-a-Service)."}
mitigation: Block malicious attachments; Disable macros; User training.

name: Dridex
notes: The operators of Dridex are widely believed to be the same group behind Locky ransomware.
tactics_techniques: Visual Basic; Native API; Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment; Process Injection: Dynamic-link Library Injection
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Evolved from Cridex. Steals banking credentials via web injection."}
mitigation: Disable macros; User training on phishing; 2FA on banking.

name: Dridex
notes: Dridex operated with Bitpaymer and other ransomware; part of 2019 malware landscape.
mitigation: Use anti-phishing training; patch Microsoft Office macros; limit macro execution.

name: Emotet
notes: Emotet botnet reactivated in August 2019 after a three‑month hiatus and continued delivering TrickBot and Ryuk as part of a malware triple threat.
tactics_techniques: ["Spam campaigns","Modular banking trojan","Delivery of other malware"]
mitigation: Use email filtering and antivirus; disable macros; apply network segmentation.

name: Dutch police arrest alleged authors of 'CoinVault' ransomware
description: Dutch police arrested two men suspected of developing the CoinVault and Bitcryptor ransomware. Authorities also obtained the decryption key database.
potential_impact_on_malware: Reduces activity of specific ransomware families; provides decryption keys to victims.
notes: Successful law enforcement action that directly led to a decryption tool being made available for victims.

name: Vulnerability in Adobe Flash Player (CVE-2016-1019)
description: A critical remote code execution vulnerability in Adobe Flash Player was disclosed and actively exploited in the wild. Patched by Adobe in APSB16-10.
potential_impact_on_malware: Enables initial access and payload delivery via exploit kits (e.g., Magnitude EK).
notes: Flash vulnerabilities were a primary vector for exploit kits delivering ransomware like Cerber and Locky in 2016.

name: TeslaCrypt operators release master decryption key
description: The operators of the TeslaCrypt ransomware shut down their operation and publicly released the master decryption key, allowing all victims to recover their files for free.
potential_impact_on_malware: Effectively ends the threat from this specific ransomware family.
metrics: {"notes":"All victims can decrypt files for free."}
notes: A rare instance of malware operators voluntarily ending their campaign and helping victims.

name: Temporary shutdown of Necurs botnet
description: The Necurs botnet, the primary distribution engine for Locky ransomware, went offline for several weeks. This caused a massive, immediate drop in Locky spam campaigns.
potential_impact_on_malware: Temporarily halts initial access for a major ransomware family.
notes: Demonstrated the critical dependency of Locky on the Necurs botnet infrastructure.

name: Mirai
notes: Source code was publicly released in Oct 2016, leading to widespread variants. Exploited weak default passwords on IoT devices like cameras and routers.
tactics_techniques: Scanning IP Blocks; Python; SSH; Default Credentials; Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder; File Deletion
persistence_mechanisms: Re-infection (persistence is weak, cleared on reboot)
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Used in record-breaking DDoS attacks (Krebs @ 620 Gbps, Dyn @ 1.2 Tbps)"}
mitigation: Change default credentials on IoT devices; Disable Telnet/SSH if unused; Network segmentation.

name: Shadow Brokers first leak
description: The Shadow Brokers group released their first cache of alleged NSA hacking tools. While the most damaging tools (like EternalBlue) were not in this initial dump, it signaled a new threat of nation-state tools being available to criminals.
potential_impact_on_malware: Signaled the future availability of highly effective exploits, which would later be used by ransomware.
notes: This event was the precursor to the 2017 leaks that enabled WannaCry and NotPetya.

name: Krebs on Security hit by record 620 Gbps DDoS
description: Brian Krebs's website was targeted by a massive DDoS attack (620 Gbps) launched by the Mirai botnet, forcing it offline. The scale of the attack was unprecedented at the time.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrated the power of IoT botnets and the massive scale of DDoS attacks they could generate.
notes: This event was the first major public demonstration of Mirai's capabilities.

name: Krebs DDoS
notes: This attack on Brian Krebs's website was one of the first major public demonstrations of the Mirai botnet's power.

name: Mirai botnet source code released
description: The source code for the Mirai botnet was publicly released on a hacking forum.
potential_impact_on_malware: Dramatically lowers the bar for creating new IoT botnets, leading to numerous variants and widespread scanning/attacks.
notes: Directly led to the proliferation of Mirai variants and the subsequent Dyn DDoS attack.

name: TrickBot
notes: TrickBot acted as a loader for Ryuk and Conti; disrupted by Microsoft and partners in October 2020.
mitigation: Implement robust email filtering; patch systems; monitor for SMB-based lateral movement.

name: TrickBot
notes: Became a key component in the Emotet-TrickBot-Ryuk infection chain, enabling high-impact ransomware attacks.
tactics_techniques: Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment; Windows Command Shell; Process Injection: Dynamic-link Library Injection; OS Credential Dumping; Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Often dropped by Emotet. Steals banking credentials, spreads laterally, and drops other malware (e.g., Ryuk ransomware)."}
mitigation: Disable macros; User training; 2FA on banking; Network segmentation.

name: Dirty COW Vulnerability (CVE-2016-5195)
description: A critical privilege escalation vulnerability in the Linux kernel was disclosed. It allowed a local user to gain root privileges.
potential_impact_on_malware: Provides a mechanism for malware on a compromised Linux host (e.g., a web server) to gain full administrative rights.
notes: A fundamental Linux vulnerability that existed for many years, impacting a vast number of servers and devices (including Android).

name: Dyn DDoS
notes: Demonstrated the systemic risk of insecure IoT devices by targeting core internet infrastructure (DNS).
tactics_techniques: Network Denial of Service; Scanning IP Blocks
impact_metrics: {"peak_bandwidth_tbps":1.2,"notes":"Massive DDoS against DNS provider Dyn, causing outages for major sites like Twitter, Netflix, Reddit."}

name: Dyn DNS DDoS Attack
description: The Mirai botnet was used to launch a 1.2 Tbps DDoS attack against DNS provider Dyn, causing widespread outages for major websites in North America and Europe, including Twitter, Netflix, and Reddit.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrated the systemic risk of insecure IoT devices to core internet infrastructure.
notes: A landmark event highlighting the real-world impact of IoT botnets.

name: Avalanche botnet infrastructure takedown
description: A global law enforcement operation dismantled the 'Avalanche' botnet infrastructure, which was a delivery platform for numerous malware families, including ransomware and banking trojans.
potential_impact_on_malware: Disrupts the C2 and delivery infrastructure for a wide range of malware families.
notes: A major success in public-private partnership to take down long-lived criminal infrastructure.

name: RSOCKS
notes: The RSOCKS botnet sold access to millions of hacked devices; law enforcement dismantled it on June 16, 2022https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdca/pr/russian-botnet-disrupted-international-cyber-operation#:~:text=SAN%20DIEGO%20%E2%80%93%20The%20U,electronic%20devices%20around%20the%20world.
mitigation: Law enforcement dismantled the botnet, users should change device passwords and apply firmware updates.

name: Apache Struts RCE (CVE-2017-5638)
description: A critical remote code execution vulnerability in Apache Struts 2 was disclosed. It was easy to exploit and allowed attackers to take full control of a web server., Apache Struts 2
related_malware_families: Enables initial access to unpatched web servers, leading to data breaches (Equifax) and potential malware deployment.
notes: The vulnerability responsible for the Equifax breach. It was patched, but Equifax failed to apply the patch.

name: WikiLeaks publishes 'Vault 7' (Year Zero)
description: WikiLeaks began publishing 'Vault 7', a series of documents detailing CIA hacking tools and capabilities. This included exploits for iOS, Android, and smart TVs.
potential_impact_on_malware: Revealed numerous zero-day vulnerabilities and nation-state cyber capabilities, increasing awareness and risk.
notes: This leak, along with the Shadow Brokers, highlighted the risk of nation-state tool proliferation.

name: Microsoft releases MS17-010
description: Microsoft released security bulletin MS17-010, which patched multiple critical vulnerabilities in the Windows SMBv1 server. This patch was critical in stopping WannaCry, but many organizations failed to apply it.
potential_impact_on_malware: Provides the primary mitigation for the EternalBlue exploit, which fueled the largest ransomware outbreaks of the year.
notes: This was the single most important patch of the year. Failure to apply it led directly to the WannaCry and NotPetya outbreaks.

name: Microsoft Office RCE (CVE-2017-0199)
description: A remote code execution vulnerability in Microsoft Office/WordPad was disclosed. It allowed code execution when a user opened a specially crafted document (e.g., RTF) containing an OLE object., Microsoft Office; WordPad
related_malware_families: Enables initial access via phishing documents. Was used as one of the infection vectors for NotPetya.
notes: This vulnerability was exploited by various malware, including as a secondary vector in the NotPetya attacks.

name: Shadow Brokers leak 'EternalBlue' exploit
description: The Shadow Brokers group leaked the 'EternalBlue' (MS17-010) and 'EternalRomance' exploits, alleged to be NSA tools. These exploits allowed for remote code execution over SMBv1.
potential_impact_on_malware: Dramatically enables wormable malware, allowing ransomware to spread automatically and rapidly across networks without user interaction.
notes: This event provided the weapon (EternalBlue) for the WannaCry and NotPetya attacks just weeks later.

name: WannaCry Outbreak
description: A massive global ransomware attack using the EternalBlue exploit (MS17-010) to spread as a worm. It crippled organizations worldwide, most notably the UK's National Health Service (NHS)., Windows
related_malware_families: Demonstrated the catastrophic impact of combining ransomware with a wormable nation-state exploit.
potential_impact_on_malware: "{""infections"":300000
notes: The first major global wormable ransomware event.

name: NotPetya Outbreak / Wiper Attack
description: A destructive wiper attack disguised as ransomware, primarily targeting Ukraine via a compromised update to M.E.Doc software. It used EternalBlue and other methods for lateral movement, causing over $10B in global damages.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrated the use of a supply-chain attack to deploy a wiper with devastating financial and operational impact.
notes: Widely considered the most financially damaging cyberattack in history.

name: AlphaBay and Hansa Market Takedown
description: A coordinated international law enforcement operation seized and shut down two of the largest dark web marketplaces, AlphaBay and Hansa.
potential_impact_on_malware: Disrupts the ecosystem for selling malware, stolen data, and other cybercrime tools.
notes: This operation disrupted a key hub for cybercriminal activity, including RaaS offerings.

name: Equifax Data Breach Announced
description: Equifax announced a massive data breach affecting 147 million people. The breach occurred from May-July 2017 by exploiting a vulnerability in Apache Struts (CVE-2017-5638).
potential_impact_on_malware: Massive loss of sensitive PII (SSNs, birth dates), providing raw material for identity theft and sophisticated phishing for years to come.
notes: One of the most significant PII breaches in history, caused by failure to patch a known vulnerability.

name: Reaper (IoTRooper)
notes: The next evolution of IoT botnets after Mirai, incorporating a library of exploits for various IoT device vulnerabilities instead of just password brute-forcing.
tactics_techniques: Exploit Public-Facing Application; Scanning IP Blocks; Python
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Evolved from Mirai but used exploits rather than brute-force. Infected millions of devices."}
mitigation: Patch IoT devices; Change default credentials; Network segmentation.

name: Huawei Router Vulnerability (CVE-2017-17215)
description: A remote code execution vulnerability in Huawei HG532 routers was disclosed. It was quickly exploited by a variant of the Mirai botnet (Satori)., Huawei HG532
related_malware_families: Provides a new vector for IoT botnets to compromise routers and add them to their network.
notes: Showed the continued evolution of IoT botnets actively incorporating new exploits.

name: Meltdown and Spectre Vulnerabilities Disclosed
description: Public disclosure of Meltdown (CVE-2017-5754) and Spectre (CVE-2017-5753, CVE-2017-5715), a class of side-channel vulnerabilities affecting nearly all modern CPUs., Most CPUs (Intel, AMD
potential_impact_on_malware: Fundamental vulnerability in hardware, potentially allowing malware to bypass memory isolation and steal sensitive data (passwords, keys) from other processes.
notes: A landmark event in hardware security, requiring massive patching efforts at the OS and firmware levels.

name: City of Atlanta hit by SamSam Ransomware
description: The City of Atlanta's municipal services were crippled by a targeted SamSam ransomware attack, disrupting services for days and costing millions in recovery., N/A
related_malware_families: Highlighted the vulnerability of municipal governments to targeted ransomware and the high recovery costs.
potential_impact_on_malware: "{""estimated_cost_usd"":8500000
notes: One of the most high-profile ransomware attacks on a US city, demonstrating the impact of 'big game hunting'.

name: VPNFilter
notes: A state-sponsored (attributed to Russia) modular botnet targeting network devices. The FBI issued a public warning urging people to reboot their routers.
tactics_techniques: Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols; Disk Wipe; Email Collection: Remote Email Collection
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Multi-stage malware targeting routers/NAS. Stage 3 was a destructive payload capable of bricking the device."}
mitigation: Reboot router (clears stage 2/3); Patch router firmware; Change default credentials.

name: First public report of LockerGoga ransomware
description: Security researchers discovered and publicly reported LockerGoga ransomware after it disrupted French engineering firm Altran. VirusTotal received the earliest sample on this date.
potential_impact_on_malware: Marked the emergence of a dangerous manual ransomware that later impacted other industrial firms.
notes: LockerGoga required manual deployment via compromised credentials.

name: LockerGoga ransomware attack hits Norsk Hydro
description: Norwegian aluminium producer Norsk Hydro suffered a major cyber-attack that forced it to shut down operations across its global organisation. Investigations linked the attack to LockerGoga ransomware.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrated destructive potential of manual ransomware in industrial environments.
notes: Hydro publicly communicated the attack and refused to pay ransom.

name: REvil uses Oracle WebLogic vulnerability (CVE-2019-2725)
description: Attackers began exploiting a deserialization flaw in Oracle WebLogic (CVE-2019-2725) to deploy the new ransomware Sodinokibi/REvil. Oracle released a patch on April 26.
potential_impact_on_malware: Enabled initial access for REvil campaigns and signaled rise of aggressive RaaS.
notes: The vulnerability allowed unauthenticated remote code execution in WebLogic.

name: Microsoft releases fix for BlueKeep (CVE-2019-0708)
description: Microsoft issued a critical patch for the remote desktop vulnerability known as BlueKeep. The wormable bug (CVE-2019-0708) could allow remote code execution on unpatched Windows systems.
potential_impact_on_malware: Unpatched systems provided potential entry points for ransomware operators until widely patched.
notes: BlueKeep exploitation was later observed in the wild in November 2019.

name: Maze pioneers double extortion with public leak site
description: Maze operationalizes data-leak sites and the double-extortion model, increasing leverage against victims.
potential_impact_on_malware: Enables post-encryption pressure via public data leaks; drives higher payouts
notes: 2019-2020 campaigns popularized data-leak extortion

name: Texas local government ransomware attack
description: A coordinated ransomware attack affected more than 20 small local government entities in Texas. The state activated its operations center and by August 23 had moved victims into recovery; no ransom was paid.
potential_impact_on_malware: Highlighted vulnerabilities in municipal networks and spurred guidance on incident response and recovery.
notes: The incident underscored the importance of preparedness in smaller government agencies.

name: Emotet botnet reactivates after three‑month hiatus
description: Check Point researchers observed the Emotet botnet resume activity in August 2019 after being dormant since June. The botnet renewed spam campaigns with malicious Word documents delivering Emotet.
potential_impact_on_malware: Reactivation boosted distribution of TrickBot and Ryuk, fueling subsequent ransomware incidents.
notes: Emotet returned as the fifth most prevalent malware in September 2019.

name: Mirai variants drive large-scale IoT DDoS
description: Proliferation of Mirai strains leveraging insecure ARM IoT devices for DDoS and proxy resale.
potential_impact_on_malware: Enables massive DDoS capacity and commoditized proxy networks
notes: Variant activity ongoing through 2019; scale depends on ISP filtering and device hygiene

name: Snatch ransomware observed rebooting Windows into Safe Mode
description: Sophos researchers discovered Snatch ransomware employing a novel technique: it forces Windows into Safe Mode to bypass security software before encrypting files.
potential_impact_on_malware: Illustrated evolving ransomware evasion tactics, prompting vendors to update detection strategies.
notes: The safe mode technique prevented many endpoint products from loading.

name: BlueKeep exploitation detected in the wild
description: By November 2019 security researchers observed active exploitation of the BlueKeep RDP vulnerability (CVE‑2019‑0708). Wormable exploits targeted unpatched systems despite Microsoft’s earlier patch release.
potential_impact_on_malware: Raised concerns about ransomware worms similar to WannaCry and prompted urgency to patch.
notes: Although exploitation was limited, it demonstrated real-world risk for unpatched systems.

name: Maze ransomware pioneers double extortion
description: Late in 2019, the Maze ransomware group began threatening to publish stolen data unless victims paid ransom, initiating the double‑extortion model that later became common among ransomware actors.
potential_impact_on_malware: Introduced a new extortion tactic that increased leverage on victims and inspired other groups (e.g., REvil, Conti).
notes: The double‑extortion model involved stealing data before encryption and threatening publication.

name: 2019 sees the “triple threat” of Emotet, TrickBot and Ryuk
description: Year‑end reports highlighted that the combination of Emotet as an initial loader, TrickBot for lateral movement, and Ryuk ransomware caused significant harm to organisations in 2019. The synergy allowed attackers to gain persistence, spread across networks and deploy destructive encryption.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrated how modular malware ecosystems amplify impact; influenced future RaaS collaborations.
notes: The triple threat remained a dominant ransomware delivery chain into 2020.

name: Ryuk/Conti affiliates target high-value enterprises
description: Affiliate-driven operations expand, focusing on enterprise ransomware with multi-million USD demands.
potential_impact_on_malware: Accelerates ransomware scale via professionalized affiliate model
notes: Conti emerging from Ryuk; campaigns intensified during 2020

name: NetWalker ransomware operators launch affiliate program
description: In March 2020, the NetWalker gang introduced a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) affiliate model, allowing other attackers to deploy its malware in exchange for a revenue share.
potential_impact_on_malware: Expanded reach of NetWalker attacks through affiliate-driven distribution.
notes: The RaaS program attracted affiliates and increased attack volume.

name: FBI identifies Ragnar Locker ransomware active since December 2019
description: Authorities discovered that the Ragnar Locker group had been attacking organisations since December 2019. The group used RDP brute‑force and the Windows COM vulnerability CVE‑2017‑0213 for privilege escalation.
potential_impact_on_malware: Showcased new techniques such as executing ransomware inside a VirtualBox VM to evade detection.
notes: The discovery emphasised the need for strong RDP security and VM monitoring.

name: TrickBot/QakBot loader infrastructure fuels ransomware
description: Persistent loader and malspam infrastructure provides initial access, credential theft, and staging for ransomware.
potential_impact_on_malware: Sustains large-scale initial access and lateral movement for ransomware operations
notes: Acted as a feeder for multiple ransomware families across 2020

name: Avaddon ransomware discovered
description: Security researchers identified a new ransomware strain named Avaddon, delivered via phishing emails with a double‑extension JavaScript downloader. It quickly evolved into a RaaS with double extortion.
potential_impact_on_malware: Illustrated the ongoing proliferation of RaaS models and social engineering tactics.
notes: Avaddon later used the Phorpiex botnet to distribute malicious spam.

name: F5 releases critical patch for BIG-IP CVE‑2020‑5902
description: F5 disclosed and patched a critical remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2020-5902) in BIG‑IP Traffic Management User Interface. The flaw allowed unauthenticated attackers to execute commands remotely.
potential_impact_on_malware: Ransomware groups could leverage unpatched BIG-IP devices for initial access; the patch mitigated risk.
notes: Follow-up guidance was released on July 8 due to active exploitation.

name: Active exploitation of F5 BIG‑IP vulnerability prompts updated guidance
description: Security researchers observed active exploitation of the BIG‑IP CVE‑2020‑5902 vulnerability. F5 released updated mitigation guidance urging customers to patch or apply workarounds.
potential_impact_on_malware: Unpatched devices were targeted by ransomware operators and other attackers for lateral movement.
notes: Demonstrated the speed at which critical vulnerabilities are weaponised.

name: DarkSide ransomware introduced
description: DarkSide ransomware first surfaced in August 2020. Operators offered a ransomware-as-a-service model and boasted about charitable donations from ransom payments.
potential_impact_on_malware: Brought professionalisation to ransomware gangs and set the stage for high-profile attacks in 2021.
notes: DarkSide later attacked Colonial Pipeline in 2021.

name: Microsoft releases Zerologon patch (CVE‑2020‑1472)
description: Microsoft issued an update addressing a critical Netlogon protocol vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472). The flaw allowed privilege escalation on domain controllers and was later dubbed Zerologon.
potential_impact_on_malware: Prevented attackers from using the vulnerability to gain domain admin privileges and deploy ransomware.
notes: Administrators were urged to apply the patch immediately to domain controllers.

name: Egregor ransomware emerges
description: Egregor ransomware was first observed in September 2020. The group used phishing emails and existing malware like Qbot/IcedID to deliver payloads and engage in double extortion.
potential_impact_on_malware: Signalled continuation of Maze operations and adoption of data leak threats by affiliates.
notes: Egregor is believed to be a successor to Sekhmet/Maze code.

name: Public disclosure and exploit of Zerologon vulnerability
description: Security firm Secura published a technical write-up on the Zerologon vulnerability, and proof-of-concept exploits became public. Attackers quickly exploited the bug to compromise Active Directory domains.
potential_impact_on_malware: Enabled ransomware groups to rapidly gain domain admin privileges and deploy payloads across networks.
notes: Exploitation increased until further Microsoft phase updates were released.

name: Microsoft and partners disrupt TrickBot botnet
description: On 12 October 2020, Microsoft and telecommunications partners launched a coordinated legal and technical action to disrupt the TrickBot botnet, cutting off servers used for command and control.
potential_impact_on_malware: Temporarily hindered distribution of ransomware via TrickBot and highlighted cooperation between private and government entities.
notes: The disruption targeted command servers and infrastructure to slow malware operations.

name: FBI issues advisory on DoppelPaymer ransomware targeting critical sectors
description: In December 2020, the FBI and CISA issued an alert warning that DoppelPaymer ransomware attacks were increasing against healthcare and critical infrastructure. The advisory highlighted the group’s data leak site and high ransom demands.
potential_impact_on_malware: Raised awareness about an active threat and provided indicators of compromise and mitigation guidance.
notes: The warning emphasised that DoppelPaymer uses Emotet and Dridex as initial access vectors.

name: Global takedown disrupts Emotet
description: International action dismantles Emotet’s infrastructure, reducing spam-driven initial access and downstream ransomware.
potential_impact_on_malware: Temporarily reduces loader availability and downstream infections
notes: Activity later resurfaced in modified forms; takedown had significant short-term impact

name: Operation Ladybird takes down Emotet botnet
description: International law enforcement agencies disrupted the Emotet botnet, replacing malware on infected computers with a law enforcement file and severing command-and-control infrastructure.
potential_impact_on_malware: Significantly reduced the distribution of malware and ransomware delivered via Emotet.
notes: The takedown involved authorities from multiple countries and was one of the largest botnet disruptions.

name: Microsoft patches Exchange Server ProxyLogon vulnerabilities
description: Microsoft released security updates fixing four zero-day vulnerabilities (CVE‑2021‑26855, CVE‑2021‑26857, CVE‑2021‑26858, CVE‑2021‑27065) exploited by the HAFNIUM threat actor to attack on-premises Exchange Server. Organisations were urged to patch immediately.
potential_impact_on_malware: Prevented attackers from leveraging SSRF and arbitrary file write to establish backdoors for ransomware deployment.
notes: These vulnerabilities were widely exploited before patches became available.

name: DarkSide hits Colonial Pipeline; REvil exploits Kaseya
description: High-profile critical infrastructure incident (Colonial Pipeline) and supply-chain event (Kaseya) illustrate impact of enterprise ransomware.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrates severe operational disruption and multi-tenant extortion via supply chains
notes: Colonial Pipeline May 7, 2021; Kaseya July 2021; both drove global response

name: Colonial Pipeline ransomware incident causes shutdown
description: DarkSide ransomware infected Colonial Pipeline’s corporate network, prompting the pipeline operator to proactively shut down operations. The shutdown led to fuel shortages until operations resumed on May 13.
potential_impact_on_malware: Highlighted the real-world consequences of ransomware on critical infrastructure and prompted policy responses.
notes: The FBI confirmed DarkSide was responsible on May 10; the US government coordinated a response.

name: JBS Foods hit by ransomware attributed to REvil
description: Meat processing giant JBS suffered a ransomware attack, leading to temporary shutdown of production facilities. The FBI attributed the attack to the REvil (Sodinokibi) group, and JBS later admitted paying an $11 million ransom.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrated that even well-resourced companies may pay ransom to avoid disruptions, potentially incentivising further attacks.
notes: JBS stated that no data was compromised and operations were largely restored at time of payment.

name: Supply-chain ransomware attack through Kaseya VSA
description: REvil affiliates exploited an authentication bypass (CVE‑2021‑30116) in Kaseya VSA remote management software to distribute ransomware to managed service providers and their clients. Kaseya urged all on-premise customers to shut down servers; a patch was released on July 11.
potential_impact_on_malware: Illustrated the risk of supply chain attacks and led to calls for stronger software vendor security.
notes: This event affected hundreds of downstream businesses across several countries.

name: Microsoft issues out-of-band updates for PrintNightmare (CVE‑2021‑34527)
description: In response to active exploitation of a Windows Print Spooler flaw, Microsoft assigned CVE‑2021‑34527 and released emergency patches on July 6–7. The vulnerability allowed remote code execution and privilege escalation.
potential_impact_on_malware: Reduced the attack surface for ransomware operators and prevented lateral movement via print spooler service.
notes: Administrators were advised to apply the patch and disable the print spooler when not needed.

name: LockBit 2.0 ransomware emerges
description: The LockBit group released version 2.0 of its ransomware-as-a-service, incorporating a data exfiltration tool (StealBIT) and adopting a double-extortion scheme.
potential_impact_on_malware: Illustrated the evolution of existing ransomware into more sophisticated RaaS models with built-in data theft.
notes: LockBit 2.0 targeted medium-to-large enterprises with high ransoms and strict affiliate rules.

name: Joint cybersecurity advisory warns about BlackMatter ransomware
description: NSA, CISA and FBI released a joint advisory warning organisations about BlackMatter ransomware. The advisory stated BlackMatter was first seen in July 2021 and provided mitigation recommendations.
potential_impact_on_malware: Raised awareness and encouraged organisations to implement protections against credential compromise and backup destruction.
notes: Advisory emphasised using multi-factor authentication and offline backups.

name: REvil ransomware gang taken offline in coordinated operation
description: A multi-country operation hacked REvil’s servers and took over its infrastructure, causing the group’s leak site and payment portal to go offline. The action followed earlier arrests of REvil affiliates.
potential_impact_on_malware: Disrupted one of the most prolific RaaS providers and signaled increased international cooperation against ransomware.
notes: REvil’s Happy Blog and payment sites disappeared following the takedown.

name: Critical Log4Shell vulnerability disclosed
description: A zero-day remote code execution vulnerability (CVE‑2021‑44228) in the Apache Log4j2 library was publicly disclosed, allowing attackers to execute code via crafted log messages. The bug affected numerous Java-based applications.
potential_impact_on_malware: Provided an extremely easy exploitation path for attackers, including ransomware groups, to gain initial access to servers.
notes: Apache released version 2.16.0 to fix the vulnerability; exploitation was observed shortly after disclosure.

name: LockBit 3.0 (Black) Released
description: LockBit RaaS developers released version 3.0, also known as LockBit Black, featuring improved encryption and triple-extortion tactics., []
related_malware_families: Increased sophistication of LockBit RaaS and expansion to new affiliates.
potential_impact_on_malware: {"victim_count_estimate": 200}
confidence_score: LockBit Black replaced version 2.0 with new features and quickly became the most deployed ransomware variant globally in 2022https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-165a#:~:text=In%202022%2C%20LockBit%20was%20the

name: RapperBot
notes: RapperBot is an IoT malware family observed since June 2022; it brute-forces SSH and Telnet credentials to build a botnet for DDoS attacks and later adapted to cryptojackinghttps://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/rapperbot-ddos-botnet-expands-into-cryptojacking#:~:text=FortiGuard%20Labs%20has%20encountered%20new
mitigation: Change default passwords on IoT devices, disable telnet/SSH, monitor for brute-force attempts.

name: RapperBot
notes: On August 19, 2025, U.S. authorities charged a suspect for operating the RapperBot botnet which infected 65k–95k devices and launched about 370,000 DDoS attacks; law enforcement terminated the botnet on August 6, 2025https://www.justice.gov/usao-ak/pr/oregon-man-charged-administering-rapper-bot-ddos-hire-botnet#:~:text=ANCHORAGE%2C%20Alaska%20%E2%80%93%20An%20Oregon,attacks%20since%20at%20least%202021.
mitigation: Reset passwords on IoT devices, disable unnecessary remote access, apply firmware updates.

name: RapperBot IoT Malware Discovered
description: Researchers identified a new IoT malware family, RapperBot, that brute-forced SSH and Telnet credentials to conscript devices into a DDoS botnet and later evolved to cryptojacking.
potential_impact_on_malware: Expanded botnet threat landscape for DDoS attacks and cryptomining.
notes: Initial campaigns were observed in June 2022, with subsequent activity in August and December; the malware persists by adding SSH keys and later pivoted to cryptomininghttps://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/rapperbot-ddos-botnet-expands-into-cryptojacking#:~:text=FortiGuard%20Labs%20has%20encountered%20new,DDoS%29%20attacks.

name: OWASSRF Exploits Disclosed
description: Rapid7 researchers reported a new exploit chain combining CVE-2022-41080 and CVE-2022-41082 (OWASSRF) that bypassed ProxyNotShell mitigations to achieve remote code execution on Exchange servers.
potential_impact_on_malware: Enabled ransomware actors to gain initial access to vulnerable Exchange servers.
notes: Rapid7 observed exploitation of the OWASSRF chain in December 2022, recommending patching to prevent remote code executionhttps://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2022/12/21/cve-2022-41080-cve-2022-41082-rapid7-observed-exploitation-of-owassrf-in-exchange-for-rce/#:~:text=Beginning%20December%2020%2C%202022%2C%20Rapid7,OWA.

name: BianLian Shifts to Data Extortion-Only

name: Hive Ransomware Infrastructure Disrupted
description: The FBI and international partners seized servers and websites used by Hive, captured decryption keys, and provided them to victims, preventing over $130 million in ransom demands.
potential_impact_on_malware: Disrupted Hive operations and prevented further attacks.
notes: Law enforcement infiltrated Hive since July 2022 and took down its servers and leak sites in January 2023https://www.justice.gov/archives/opa/pr/us-department-justice-disrupts-hive-ransomware-variant#:~:text=Office%20of%20Public%20Affairs.

name: Akira Ransomware Discovered
description: Akira ransomware surfaced in March 2023, conducting double-extortion attacks worldwide, later developing Rust variants and Linux version targeting ESXi servers.
potential_impact_on_malware: Introduces a new aggressive RaaS with multiplatform capabilities.
notes: Akira affected over 250 organizations by January 2024 and targeted VPN services without MFA, using C++ and Rust payloadshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-109a#:~:text=The%20United%20States%E2%80%99%20Federal%20Bureau,as%20recently%20as%20February%202024https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-109a#:~:text=The%20FBI%20and%20cybersecurity%20researchers,4%20%28link%20is%20external.

name: Rhysida Ransomware Emerges
description: Security researchers observed the emergence of the Rhysida ransomware-as-a-service group, which targets organizations worldwide via compromised VPN credentials and Zerologon exploitation.
potential_impact_on_malware: Adds a new RaaS threat targeting multiple sectors.
notes: Rhysida primarily affects education, healthcare, manufacturing, IT, and government sectors; it leverages stolen VPN credentials and the Zerologon vulnerabilityhttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2023/11/15/cisa-fbi-and-ms-isac-release-advisory-rhysida-ransomware#:~:text=ransomware%20indicators%20of%20compromise%20,as%20recently%20as%20September%202023.

name: MOVEit Transfer Zero-Day Exploited by CL0P

name: Operation Endgame Neutralizes Initial Access Malware
description: Law enforcement agencies from multiple countries coordinated to dismantle infrastructure used by initial access malware including Bumblebee, Lactrodectus, Qakbot, HijackLoader, DanaBot, Trickbot, and Warmcookie, taking down ~300 servers and 650 domains and issuing 20 arrest warrants.
potential_impact_on_malware: Severely disrupted delivery of ransomware by removing key loaders and initial access tools.
notes: Operation Endgame targeted multiple loaders used by ransomware groups, neutralizing malware and seizing infrastructure and cryptocurrencyhttps://eucrim.eu/news/operation-endgame-targets-initial-access-malware/#:~:text=At%20the%20end%20of%20May,Hijackloader%2C%20DanaBot%2C%20Trickbot%2C%20and%20Warmcookie.

name: Play Ransomware Update Published
description: CISA and partners released an updated advisory on Play ransomware describing its exploitation of SimpleHelp vulnerability (CVE-2024-57727) and other CVEs, and noting that the group had affected around 900 entities.
potential_impact_on_malware: Encourages organizations to patch widely exploited vulnerabilities to prevent Play intrusions.
notes: The update emphasizes that Play exploits new remote management vulnerabilities and remains a major ransomware threat impacting roughly 900 entitieshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-352a#:~:text=Initial%20Accesshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2025/06/04/updated-guidance-play-ransomware#:~:text=Read%20Full%20Advisory%20Text.

name: Interlock Ransomware Alert Issued
description: CISA released a joint advisory on Interlock ransomware detailing its drive-by download infection method disguised as browser updates, use of the ClickFix trick, virtualization-specific encryption, and double-extortion approach.
potential_impact_on_malware: Highlights emergence of virtualization-targeting ransomware and stresses need for user awareness against fake browser updates.
notes: The advisory explains that Interlock uses a ClickFix CAPTCHA to trick users, exfiltrates data via Azure Storage tools, and encrypts virtual machines for ransomhttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa25-203a#:~:text=The%20Interlock%20ransomware%20variant%20was,other%20systems%20on%20the%20networkhttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa25-203a#:~:text=FBI%20has%20observed%20Interlock%20actors,2.

name: Scattered Spider / Octo Tempest Update Published
description: CISA issued an alert about Scattered Spider (Octo Tempest) detailing its sophisticated social-engineering tactics such as IT helpdesk impersonation, SIM swapping, push bombing, and use of remote access tools, as well as its deployment of DragonForce ransomware.
potential_impact_on_malware: Raises awareness of advanced social-engineering campaigns targeting large companies.

name: RapperBot Botnet Operator Indicted
description: Federal prosecutors charged a Missouri man with operating the RapperBot botnet, which infected tens of thousands of IoT devices and launched hundreds of thousands of DDoS attacks; the botnet was neutralized earlier in August.
potential_impact_on_malware: Reduces availability of a major DDoS-for-hire botnet and deters similar operators.
notes: The indictment notes the botnet targeted victims in over 80 countries and that law enforcement terminated the infrastructure on August 6, 2025https://www.justice.gov/usao-ak/pr/oregon-man-charged-administering-rapper-bot-ddos-hire-botnet#:~:text=ANCHORAGE%2C%20Alaska%20%E2%80%93%20An%20Oregon,attacks%20since%20at%20least%202021.

name: Microsoft SMB Client Vulnerability CVE-2025-33073 Actively Exploited
description: CISA and Microsoft warned that a privilege escalation flaw in the Windows SMB client (CVE-2025-33073) was being exploited in the wild, allowing attackers to run arbitrary code and take over systems.
potential_impact_on_malware: Provides an additional avenue for privilege escalation and ransomware deployment on Windows systems.
notes: Help Net Security summarised CISA’s warning that CVE-2025-33073 allows elevation of privilege and remote command execution; agencies were instructed to remediate by November 10, 2025https://www.helpnetsecurity.com/2025/10/21/cisa-warns-of-windows-smb-flaw-under-active-exploitation-cve-2025-33073/#:~:text=CVE,is%20being%20exploited%20by%20attackershttps://www.helpnetsecurity.com/2025/10/21/cisa-warns-of-windows-smb-flaw-under-active-exploitation-cve-2025-33073/#:~:text=,and%20unveiled%20by%20watchTowr%20researchers.

name: CISA Adds 2025 CVEs to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog
description: CISA added five vulnerabilities – CVE-2022-48503, CVE-2025-2746, CVE-2025-2747, CVE-2025-33073, and CVE-2025-61884 – to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog, citing active exploitation and urging remediation by November 10, 2025.
potential_impact_on_malware: Signals that threat actors are exploiting newly disclosed vulnerabilities, prompting urgent patching.
notes: CISA’s alert states that these CVEs are actively exploited and pose significant risks to federal enterpriseshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2025/10/20/cisa-adds-five-known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog#:~:text=October%2020%2C%202025.

name: Qakbot
notes: Operation Endgame (May 2025) neutralised the Qakbot malware as part of a crackdown on initial access malware delivering ransomware; investigators took down around 300 servers, 650 domains, issued 20 arrest warrants and seized €3.5 millionhttps://eucrim.eu/news/operation-endgame-targets-initial-access-malware/#:~:text=At%20the%20end%20of%20May,Hijackloader%2C%20DanaBot%2C%20Trickbot%2C%20and%20Warmcookie.
mitigation: Law enforcement took down infrastructure; organizations should block malicious attachments and apply email filtering.

name: Trickbot
notes: Operation Endgame (May 2025) neutralised the Trickbot malware as part of a crackdown on initial access malware delivering ransomware; investigators took down around 300 servers, 650 domains, issued 20 arrest warrants and seized €3.5 millionhttps://eucrim.eu/news/operation-endgame-targets-initial-access-malware/#:~:text=At%20the%20end%20of%20May,Hijackloader%2C%20DanaBot%2C%20Trickbot%2C%20and%20Warmcookie.
mitigation: Law enforcement took down infrastructure; organizations should block malicious attachments and apply email filtering.
